meanings.definition: Make (something) ineffective by applying an opposite force or effect.
meanings.sent1: She was neutralising the sour taste of the lemon by adding sugar.
meanings.sent2: The antidote worked by neutralising the venom in the snake bite.
meanings.sent3: The superhero's power was neutralising the villain's evil plans effortlessly.
meanings.sent4: Her smile had a way of neutralising any tension in the room.
meanings.sent5: The firefighter's quick response was neutralising the spreading flames effectively.

meanings.definition: Counteract or cancel out the effect of (something).
meanings.sent1: Eating a banana can help neutralising the potassium loss during exercise.
meanings.sent2: The new medicine aims to neutralise the symptoms of the allergy.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick involved neutralising the impact of the falling object with a hidden cushion.
meanings.sent4: Her laughter seemed to neutralise the seriousness of the situation.
meanings.sent5: The detective's keen observation skills were neutralising the criminal's attempts to escape.

meanings.sent1: The acid and base neutralised each other, neutralising the solution.
meanings.sent2: After the argument, they both agreed to neutralise their feelings towards each other.
meanings.sent3: The color of the chameleon was neutralising to match the surroundings perfectly.
meanings.sent4: The negotiation process was like neutralising a ticking time bomb.
meanings.sent5: The music had a calming effect, neutralising the stress of the busy day.
